Peffer]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1833|12|29}} |birth_place = [[Middleton, Massachusetts|Middleton]], [[Massachusetts]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1900|8|16|1833|12|29}} |death_place = [[Las Vegas, New Mexico|Las Vegas]], [[New Mexico]] |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] }} '''John James Ingalls''' (December 29, 1833{{spaced ndash}}August 16, 1900) was an [[United States|American]] politician. John James Ingalls was born in [[Middleton, Massachusetts|Middleton]], [[Massachusetts]], on December 29, 1833. He graduated from [[Williams College]] in 1855. Foreshadowing his later reputation as a wit, his graduation thesis, entitled ''Mummy Life'', was a satire of college life. He studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1857. Moving to [[Kansas Territory]], Ingalls settled in [[Atchison, Kansas|Atchison]] in 1860. He joined the anti-slavery forces and worked to make [[Kansas]] a free state. He was a member of the [[Wyandotte Constitution|Wyandotte constitutional convention]] in 1859 and is reputed to have coined the state motto, ''[[Ad astra (phrase)|Ad Astra per Aspera]]''. When Kansas was admitted to the Union in 1861, he became secretary of the first state Senate and state senator in 1862. During the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] he served as judge advocate in the Kansas militia. As an editor of the Atchison newspaper, ''Freedom's Champion'', for three years, he won a national reputation for a series of magazine articles. Elected to the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] in 1873, succeeding [[Samuel C. Pomeroy]], Ingalls served for 18 years. He supported labor and agriculture against monopolies. He also favored the [[Interstate Commerce Act]] and the [[Pendleton Civil Service Act]]. In 1887 Ingalls was elected President pro tempore of the Senate. Praised throughout his life for his keen sarcasm and quick wit, John James Ingalls died in [[Las Vegas, New Mexico]] on August 16, 1900. In 1905, the state of Kansas donated a marble statue of Ingalls to the [[U.S. Capitol]]'s [[National Statuary Hall Collection]].<ref>http://www.aoc.gov/cc/art/nsh/ingalls.cfm</ref> Currently Kansas has plans to replace Ingalls with [[Amelia Earhart]].<ref>[http://cjonline.com/life/connected/2011-03-12/amelias-monument-about-take-flight Amelia's monument about to take flight]</ref> ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} {{CongBio|I000012}} {{S-start}} {{s-par|us-sen}} {{U.S. Senator box |state=Kansas |class=3 |before=[[Samuel C.
